Special Issue Editorial: Multisensory interaction in virtual environments

  • Published: 09 May 2006

Special Issue Editorial: Multisensory interaction in virtual environments

  • Antonio Frisoli1 &
  • Antonio Camurri2 

Virtual Reality volume 10, pages2–3(2006)Cite this article

  • 114 Accesses

  • 1 Citations

  • Metrics details

This special issue on “Multisensory Interaction in Virtual Environments” is promoted by the European Network of Excellence ENACTIVE (http://www.enactivenetwork.org). It follows the second International Conference on Enactive Interfaces ENACTIVE 2005 (http://www.enactive2005.org), held in the beautiful historical setting of Casa Paganini, a new centre of excellence of University of Genova (http://www.casapaganini.org), Italy on November 18–19, 2005 and chaired by the guest editors of this issue. The six papers here included followed a peer review process starting from the accepted papers presented at ENACTIVE 2005. The conference was a great success in terms of participation (more than 120 registered participants), and attracted researchers from various disciplines, including computer science and engineering, cognitive sciences, psychology, human factors, and interaction design.

The focus of this issue is on multisensory and enactive human–computer interaction in virtual environments, with a special emphasis on new paradigms of interaction. The broader scope is to contribute to the growth of a truly multidisciplinary research community on the new generation of human–computer interfaces called enactive interfaces.

Multimodal human–computer interfaces integrate input and output modalities, such as audio, speech, vision, gesture and touch. Enactive interfaces are related to an advance of the multimodal paradigm, a fundamental “interaction” concept which is not yet fully exploited in most of the existing human–computer multimodal interfaces.

Enactive knowledge goes beyond multisensory-mediated knowledge: it represents the kind of knowledge “learned by doing”, based on the experience of perceptual responses to action, acquired by demonstration and sharpened by practice. According to Varela’s model of “enactive cognition” (Varela et al. 1991), enactive knowledge is primarily “knowledge for action”, and conversely, action is always necessary to acquire knowledge (J. Stewart, Enactive knowledge in Enactive Lexicon, http://www.enactivenetwork.org). This type of knowledge transmission can be considered the most direct, in the sense that it is natural and intuitive, since it is based on the experience and on the perceptual responses to motor acts.

For example, typical tasks requiring a high degree of enactive knowledge are dancing or playing a musical instrument, moulding shapes in clay or engraving, driving a car or suturing a wound by a surgeon. As a consequence of the above assumptions, physical embodiment is a necessary condition for the acquisition of enactive knowledge: this consideration is particularly relevant for Virtual Reality since the level of immersion and the degree of interaction that is established within the environment is determined by the extent that sensory modalities responses can be mimicked in the simulated scenario.

Human–computer interfaces should be able to display to the human subject the possibilities for actions available in the environment, to evoke them as natural (Gibson’s affordances), actions that are relevant to the organism’s goal-directed behavior. Evoking affordances in virtual environments is linked to the possibility of displaying appropriate correlated multisensorial stimuli to the subject: the immersiveness of the experience alone does not in fact necessarily lead to a natural interaction, if the user cannot perceive what can be done via the interface (Gross et al. 2005).

Even if up to now HCI technologies have not fully exploited the potential of enactive multisensory-mediated knowledge, recent technological advances—e.g. in gesture tracking, in sensory integration, and in improved 3D frameworks—have created the possibility in virtual environments to significantly enhance naturally display possibilities for action and for direct manipulation of data, overall guaranteeing the capacity for continuing action and enaction in the environment.

The articles included in this issue are concerned with different sensorial modalities and interfaces, including visual, haptic, auditory and gesture tracking interfaces. All the articles address either specific issues or general concepts related to the implementation of virtual environments providing a meaningful multisensorial stimulation to the user, capable of effectively and actively engaging him/her in the simulated scenario.

In the first paper of this issue “Affordances in the design of enactive systems”, Thomas A. Stoffregen, Benoit Bardy and Bruno Mantel revise the role of affordances in the design of virtual environments and interfaces, showing how different subjects can make correct judgments of affordances, based on the observation of plausible biological intuitive motions and observed correlations with the environment. They show also how the modulation of perception by action of the viewer represents the further step that is needed to implement actually enactive displays.

A pre-requisite for intuitive manipulative interaction in virtual environments is constituted by reaching and grasping virtual objects in a natural way (Bergamasco et al. 2006). This relies on the possibility of achieving stable grasping with multiple fingers, without limitation in terms of workspace and possibly with co-location, either in space or in time, of perceived visual, haptic or auditory stimuli. These issues are investigated in the next three papers presented in the issue.

In the paper “A mobile platform for haptic grasping in large environments”, Maurizio de Pascale, Alessandro Formaglio and Domenico Prattichizzo present a mobile platform for haptic grasping in virtual environments, where the limitations due to the reduced size of workspace of traditional desktop haptic devices are overcome by mounting them on the actuated base of a mobile robot. A suitable control strategy is selected in order to guarantee the stability of the interaction and a smooth tracking of user’s trajectories.

The issue of co-location in the visual–haptic interaction in virtual environments is analyzed in the third paper “Interaction with co-located haptic feedback in virtual reality” by David Swapp, Vijay Pawar and Celine Loscos. The performance of human subjects is analyzed in three different tasks of spatial accuracy, manipulation and response under different conditions of co-location of visual and haptic stimuli, showing that significant benefits can arise from co-location of visual and haptic stimuli.

Also auditory feedback can modify and improve performance and sensorial perception during visuo–haptic interaction with objects. Iñaki Díaz, Josune Hernantes, Ignacio Mansa, Alberto Lozano, Diego Borro, Jorge Juan Gil and Emilio Sanchez present in the paper “Influence of multisensory feedback on Haptic Accessibility Tasks” a user study where participants perform an accessibility task with the aid of different combinations of sensorial stimuli, including visual, auditory and haptic feedback. They show how the addition of the auditory feedback can improve the performance of haptic feedback, in terms of accuracy of user’s trajectories.

The next paper “Virtual Bounds: A Teleoperated Mixed Reality”, by Kevin Ponto, Falko Kuester, Robert Nideffer and Simon Penny presents an original mixed-reality set-up, where the interaction of the user with the simulated scenario is realized through a real probe, controlled by the user, and allowed to interact with virtual entities. The probe implements the conditions for telepresence of the user in a virtual simulated scenario and the authors show how the performance with a real-world perspective increases with respect to the solely teleoperation perspective.

Perception of our own body, e.g. body stature and size, in the virtual environment constitutes also a determinant factor for correct undertaking of actions and behaviors in the environment (Gross et al. 2005). The fidelity of real-time recovery and the plausibility of displayed body postures is analyzed in the paper “Evaluation of on-line analytic and numeric inverse kinematics approaches driven by partial vision input” by Ronan Boulic, Javier Varona, Luis Unzueta, Manual Peinado, Angel Suescun and Francisco Perales, where the authors compare the performance of analytical and numerical inverse kinematic techniques for the purpose of postural control and animation of virtual avatars.

The perception of body motion is determinant for the control of artistic expressivity of body gestures, such as in dance performance, but expressivity is a also relevant aspect for auditory interfaces and musical gestures.

The modeling and synthesis of expressive content in musical signals, and its communication via auditory interfaces, constitutes an important channel to enhance the overall sense of presence as well as to influence the emotional processes of subjects immersed in virtual reality experiences. The paper ending this special issue, “Analysis of expression in simple musical gestures to enhance audio in interfaces” by Luca Mion and Gianluca D’Incà, develops a model for analysis and synthesis of expressive sounds.

In conclusion, we would like to thank the journal editors for accepting the proposal of this special issue, all the reviewers for the timely and accurate revisions of papers and most of all the submitting authors for their contributions to this important topic of research, with the hope that will foster the discussion and the future research in this area.
